intro.para: Here we establish two basic properties of linear transformations.

li.para: A linear transformation L\from \RNr[n]\to \RNr[m] always maps the zero-vector of \RNr[n] to the zero-vector of \RNr[m]. – Whenever a function f\from \RNr[n]\to \RNr[m] fails to satisfy f(\Vect{0})=\Vect{0}, f can not be linear.

A function \RNr[n]\to \RNr[m] is linear transformation if and only if it sends each linear motion in \RNr[n] to a linear motion in \RNr[n]. – This is a geometric characterization of linear transformation.

section.body.para: The condition L(\Vect{0})=\Vect{0} is necessary for L to be linear. It is, however, not sufficient because there are functions f\from \RNr[n]\to \RNr[m] with f(\Vect{0})=\Vect{0}, and still they are not linear.
